sn1.36:0.2.eng: 4. The Host of a Hundred Felicities

sn1.36:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn1.36:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn1.36:1.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā satullapakāyikā devatāyo abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
sn1.36:1.2.eng: Then, late at night, several glorious deities of the host of a hundred felicities, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.

sn1.36:1.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho ekā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.36:1.3.eng: Standing to one side, one deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
sn1.36:1.3.comm: The Pali text attributes none of the verses to the Buddha. However, in the two Chinese parallels at SA 1286 and SA-2 284, one deity gives an opening verse; the Buddha responds with a series of 5 or 6 verses; then the deity concludes with a verse in praise. This gives a much more satisfying structure, and it seems likely the Pali text has suffered loss.

sn1.36:2.1.comm: This sounds like a typical deity verse in that it culminates by going to heaven, but it is attributed to the Buddha in the Chinese parallels.

sn1.36:2.3.pli: Yaso ca kittī ca tatvassa hoti,

sn1.36:2.4.eng: and when they discard this corpse they go to heaven.”

sn1.36:3.1.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn1.36:3.1.eng: Then another deity recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.36:4.1.eng: “Give up anger, get rid of conceit,
sn1.36:4.1.comm: This verse sounds unlike something a deity would say, and like something the Buddha would say.

sn1.36:4.2.eng: and get past all the fetters.

sn1.36:4.3.eng: Chains don’t torment one who has nothing,

sn1.36:4.4.eng: not clinging to name and form.”
sn1.36:4.4.comm: While the deity is said to recite several verses, the Pali text finishes here with a close -ti indicating the end of the quote.

sn1.36:5.1.comm: The Pali text indicates no speaker for the final verses, but presumably they too were spoken by the Buddha.

sn1.36:6.3.eng: For if you’re diligent and practice absorption,

sn1.37:0.2.eng: 4. The Host of a Hundred Felicities

sn1.37:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ mahāvane mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sabbeheva arahantehi;
sn1.37:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, in the Great Wood near Kapilavatthu, together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants, all of whom were perfected ones.
sn1.37:1.2.comm: This discourse is the same as the first section of DN 20.

sn1.37:1.3.pli: dasahi ca lokadhātūhi devatā yebhuyyena sannipatitā honti bhagavantaṃ dassanāya bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn1.37:1.3.eng: And most of the deities from ten solar systems had gathered to see the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants.

sn1.37:1.4.pli: Atha kho catunnaṃ suddhāvāsakāyikānaṃ devatānaṃ etadahosi:
sn1.37:1.4.eng: Then four deities of the Pure Abodes, aware of what was happening, thought:
sn1.37:1.4.comm: The Pure Abodes (suddhāvāsā) are realms into which only nonreturners can be reborn. They are reckoned as five: Aviha, Atappa, Sudassa, Sudassı̄, and Akaniṭṭha.

sn1.37:1.5.pli: “ayaṃ kho bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ mahāvane mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sabbeheva arahantehi;

sn1.37:1.6.pli: dasahi ca lokadhātūhi devatā yebhuyyena sannipatitā honti bhagavantaṃ dassanāya bhikkhusaṅghañca.

sn1.37:1.7.pli: Yannūna mayampi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkameyyāma; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato santike paccekaṃ gāthaṃ bhāseyyāmā”ti.
sn1.37:1.7.eng: “Why don’t we go to the Buddha and each recite a verse in his presence?”

sn1.37:2.1.pli: Atha kho tā devatā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—suddhāvāsesu devesu antarahitā bhagavato purato pāturahesuṃ.
sn1.37:2.1.eng: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, they vanished from the Pure Abodes and reappeared in front of the Buddha.

sn1.37:2.2.pli: Atha kho tā devatā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
sn1.37:2.2.eng: They bowed to the Buddha and stood to one side.

sn1.37:2.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho ekā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.37:2.3.eng: Standing to one side, one deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.37:3.1.eng: “There’s a great congregation in the woods,

sn1.37:3.2.eng: where hosts of gods have assembled.

sn1.37:3.3.eng: We’ve come to this righteous congregation

sn1.37:4.1.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.37:4.1.eng: Then another deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.37:5.3.eng: Like a charioteer holding the reins,

sn1.37:5.4.eng: the astute ones protect their senses.”

sn1.37:6.1.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.37:6.1.eng: Then another deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.37:7.1.eng: “They snapped the post and snapped the cross-bar,
sn1.37:7.1.comm: Read khīla (“post”) rather than khila (“barrenness”).

sn1.37:7.2.eng: unstirred, they tore out Indra’s pillar.
sn1.37:7.2.comm: A village (Bu Pj 2:3.8) or royal compound (Bu Pc 83:1.3.56.1) was marked with a “boundary-post” (indakhīla). It symbolized a fixed and immovable point, either in a good sense (SN 56.39:4.1) or, as here, an obstacle. The Sanskrit indrakīla is a two-foot long iron bolt securing a fort, presumably fixed in the ground (Arthaśāstra 2.3.26), or else a mountain in the Himalayas. The warrior Arjuna, journeying beyond the Gandhamādana, is stopped at the Indrakīla mountain by Sakra/Indra disguised as a brahmin ascetic, at whose urging Arjuna undertakes asceticism in order to gain the power he would need (Mahābhārata 3.3.37). The symbolic sense of “stopping” relates to the Pali sense of immovability, and suggests that the underlying metaphor is the irresistible power represented by Indra.

sn1.37:7.4.eng: the young giants tamed by the Clear-eyed One.”
sn1.37:7.4.comm: The primary sense of nāga seems to be “snake”, especially the cobra. From there it applies to other powerful beings: the elephant, the dragon, and as here, the spiritual “giants” of the Saṅgha.

sn1.37:8.1.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.37:8.1.eng: Then another deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.37:9.1.eng: “Anyone who has gone to the Buddha for refuge

sn1.37:9.2.eng: won’t go to a plane of loss.

sn1.37:9.3.eng: After giving up this human body,

sn1.37:9.4.eng: they swell the hosts of gods.”

sn1.38:0.2.eng: 4. The Host of a Hundred Felicities

sn1.38:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati maddakucchismiṃ migadāye.
sn1.38:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Maddakucchi deer park.

sn1.38:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavato pādo sakalikāya khato hoti.
sn1.38:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha’s foot had been cut by a wooden splinter.
sn1.38:1.3.comm: This may not be the same event recorded at Kd 17:3.9.11 where a stone chip injured the Buddha’s foot. Here it is sakalikā, a wooden splinter (eg. SN 12.55:4.4, SN 35.246:4.20).

sn1.38:1.4.pli: Bhusā sudaṃ bhagavato vedanā vattanti sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā;
sn1.38:1.4.eng: The Buddha was stricken by harrowing pains; physical feelings that were painful, sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, and disagreeable.

sn1.38:1.5.pli: tā sudaṃ bhagavā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno.
sn1.38:1.5.eng: But he endured unbothered, with mindfulness and situational awareness.

sn1.38:1.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññāpetvā dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappeti pāde pādaṃ accādhāya sato sampajāno.
sn1.38:1.6.eng: And then he spread out his outer robe folded in four and laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.

sn1.38:2.1.pli: Atha kho sattasatā satullapakāyikā devatāyo abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ maddakucchiṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
sn1.38:2.1.eng: Then, late at night, seven hundred glorious deities of the host of a hundred felicities, lighting up the entire Maddakucchi, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.

sn1.38:2.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho ekā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
sn1.38:2.2.eng: Standing to one side, one deity expressed this heartfelt sentiment in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.38:2.3.eng: “The ascetic Gotama is such an elephant, sir!

sn1.38:2.4.pli: nāgavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
sn1.38:2.4.eng: And as an elephant, he endures painful physical feelings that have come up—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, and disagreeable—unbothered, with mindfulness and situational awareness.”

sn1.38:3.1.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
sn1.38:3.1.eng: Then another deity expressed this heartfelt sentiment in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.38:3.2.eng: “The ascetic Gotama is such a lion, sir!

sn1.38:3.3.pli: sīhavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
sn1.38:3.3.eng: And as a lion, he endures painful physical feelings … unbothered.”

sn1.38:4.1.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
sn1.38:4.1.eng: Then another deity expressed this heartfelt sentiment in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.38:4.2.eng: “The ascetic Gotama is such a thoroughbred, sir!

sn1.38:4.3.pli: ājānīyavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
sn1.38:4.3.eng: And as a thoroughbred, he endures painful physical feelings … unbothered.”

sn1.38:5.1.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
sn1.38:5.1.eng: Then another deity expressed this heartfelt sentiment in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.38:5.2.eng: “The ascetic Gotama is such a boss bull, sir!

sn1.38:5.3.pli: nisabhavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
sn1.38:5.3.eng: And as a boss bull, he endures painful physical feelings … unbothered.”

sn1.38:6.1.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
sn1.38:6.1.eng: Then another deity expressed this heartfelt sentiment in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.38:6.2.eng: “The ascetic Gotama is such a behemoth, sir!
sn1.38:6.2.comm: “Behemoth” is dhorayha, literally “beast of burden”, a draft-horse or ox.

sn1.38:6.3.pli: dhorayhavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
sn1.38:6.3.eng: And as a behemoth, he endures painful physical feelings … unbothered.”

sn1.38:7.1.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
sn1.38:7.1.eng: Then another deity expressed this heartfelt sentiment in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.38:7.2.eng: “The ascetic Gotama is truly tamed, sir!

sn1.38:7.3.pli: dantavatā ca samuppannā sārīrikā vedanā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno”ti.
sn1.38:7.3.eng: And as someone tamed, he endures painful physical feelings … unbothered.”

sn1.38:8.1.pli: Atha kho aparā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
sn1.38:8.1.eng: Then another deity expressed this heartfelt sentiment in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.38:8.2.pli: “passa samādhiṃ subhāvitaṃ cittañca suvimuttaṃ, na cābhinataṃ na cāpanataṃ na ca sasaṅkhāraniggayhavāritagataṃ.
sn1.38:8.2.eng: “See, his immersion is so well developed, and his mind is so well freed—not leaning forward or pulling back, and not held in place by forceful suppression.

sn1.38:8.3.pli: Yo evarūpaṃ purisanāgaṃ purisasīhaṃ purisaājānīyaṃ purisanisabhaṃ purisadhorayhaṃ purisadantaṃ atikkamitabbaṃ maññeyya kimaññatra adassanā”ti.
sn1.38:8.3.eng: If anyone imagines that they can overcome such an elephant of a man, a lion of a man, a thoroughbred of a man, a boss bull of a man, a behemoth of a man, a tamed man—what is that but a failure to see?”

sn1.38:9.1.eng: “Learned in the five branches of Vedic lore,
sn1.38:9.1.comm: Pali texts frequently refer to the five branches of Vedic lore: the three Vedas, linguistics, and the legendary “testaments as fifth” (DN 3:1.3.1). Chāndogya Upaniṣad 7.1.4 likewise mentions the Rig, Yajur, and Samn Veda, the Atharva as fourth, and the “legendary testaments as fifth of the Vedas”. | Sataṁ samaṁ also describes Vedic practice at Dhp 106.

sn1.38:9.2.eng: brahmins practice fervent mortification for a full century.

sn1.38:9.3.eng: But their minds are not properly freed,
sn1.38:9.3.comm: The Buddha’s equanimity in the face of pain is contrasted with those ascetics who, even though they actively pursue pain through their mortifications, still do not purify their minds.

sn1.38:9.4.eng: for those of base character don’t cross to the far shore.

sn1.38:10.1.eng: Seized by craving,  <j>attached to precept and observance,

sn1.38:10.2.eng: they practice rough and fervent mortification for a hundred years.

sn1.38:10.3.eng: But their minds are not properly freed,

sn1.38:10.4.eng: for those of base character don’t cross to the far shore.

sn1.38:11.1.eng: Someone who’s fond of conceit can’t be tamed,

sn1.38:11.2.eng: and someone without immersion can’t be a sage.

sn1.38:11.3.eng: Living negligent alone in the wilderness,

sn1.38:11.4.eng: they can’t cross beyond Death’s dominion.”

sn1.38:12.1.eng: “Having given up conceit, serene within oneself,

sn1.38:12.2.eng: with a good heart, everywhere free;

sn1.38:12.3.eng: living diligent alone in the wilderness,

sn1.39:0.2.eng: 4. The Host of a Hundred Felicities

sn1.39:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn1.39:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

sn1.39:1.3.pli: Atha kho kokanadā pajjunnassa dhītā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ mahāvanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn1.39:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious Kokanadā, Pajjunna’s daughter, lighting up the entire Great Wood, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,
sn1.39:1.3.comm: Pajjuna is Parjanya, the Vedic god of rain, especially the thunderstorm. His “lively drops” impregnate the earth, begetting plants (Rig Veda 5.83). While I cannot find a reference elsewhere to his daughter Kokanadā, it seems fitting that the daughter of the rain and the earth is the “Red Lotus”.

sn1.39:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā kokanadā pajjunnassa dhītā bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn1.39:1.4.eng: and recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.39:2.2.eng: is the Buddha, best of creation.
sn1.39:2.2.comm: Bodhi suggests taking the singular sattassa as a metrically shortened sattānaṁ (“beings”). However, there is a plural form sattāna that is metrically identical with sattassa. Perhaps Kokanadā is using satta here in the sense of “creation”.

sn1.39:2.3.eng: Kokanadā am I who worships him,

sn1.39:3.2.eng: the teaching realized by the Clear-eyed One.

sn1.39:3.3.eng: But now I know it as a witness

sn1.39:3.4.eng: while the sage, the Holy One teaches.

sn1.39:4.1.eng: There are simpletons who go about

sn1.39:4.2.eng: denouncing the teaching of the noble ones.

sn1.39:4.3.eng: They fall into the terrible Hell of Screams
sn1.39:4.3.comm: The commentaries identify this  roruva (“Hell of Screams”) with the “Smoky Roruva”, while the “Great Hell of Screams”, mentioned as the destiny of a corrupt financier in SN 3.20, is the “Flaming Roruva”, said to be the same as Avīci. These are also known in the Sanskrit tradition, eg. Manu 4.88, and described in detail at eg. Mārkaṇḍeya Purāṇa 10, 12. There, the Ruarava of glowing coals is the destiny of the false witness and the liar, while Mahāraurava is scorching copper and ravenous beasts.

sn1.39:4.4.comm: Torment in the Mahāraurava lasts 100,000,000 years, according to the Mārkaṇḍeya Purāṇa.

sn1.39:5.1.eng: There are those who have found  <j>acceptance and peace

sn1.39:5.2.eng: in the teaching of the noble ones.

sn1.39:5.3.eng: After giving up this human body,

sn1.39:5.4.eng: they swell the hosts of gods.”

sn1.4:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.4:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, that deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.4:2.2.eng: the stages of life leave us one by one.

sn1.4:2.4.eng: do good deeds that bring you joy.”

sn1.4:3.2.eng: the stages of life leave us one by one.

sn1.4:3.4.eng: a seeker of peace would drop the world’s bait.”

sn1.40:0.2.eng: 4. The Host of a Hundred Felicities

sn1.40:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn1.40:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

sn1.40:1.3.pli: Atha kho cūḷakokanadā pajjunnassa dhītā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ mahāvanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn1.40:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious Kokanadā the Younger, Pajjunna’s daughter, lighting up the entire Great Wood, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,

sn1.40:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā cūḷakokanadā pajjunnassa dhītā bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn1.40:1.4.eng: and recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.40:2.1.eng: “She came here, beautiful as a flash of lightning,
sn1.40:2.1.comm: An apt description of the daughter of the thunderstorm.

sn1.40:2.3.eng: Revering the Buddha and the teaching,

sn1.40:2.4.eng: she spoke these verses full of meaning.

sn1.40:3.2.eng: I could analyze it in many different ways.

sn1.40:3.3.eng: However, I will state the meaning in brief

sn1.40:3.4.eng: as far as I have learned it by heart.

sn1.40:4.1.eng: You should never do anything bad

sn1.40:4.2.eng: by speech or mind or body in all the world.

sn1.40:4.3.eng: Having given up sensual pleasures,  <j>mindful and aware,

sn1.40:4.4.eng: you shouldn’t keep doing  <j>what’s painful and pointless.”

sn1.41:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn1.41:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.

sn1.41:1.3.pli: Atha kho aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn1.41:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,

sn1.41:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn1.41:1.4.eng: and recited these verses in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.41:3.1.eng: And as the world is on fire

sn1.41:4.1.eng: What’s given has happiness as its fruit,

sn1.41:4.4.eng: it’s consumed by fire, or lost.

sn1.41:5.1.eng: Then in the end this corpse is cast off,

sn1.41:5.4.eng: would enjoy what they have and also give it away.

sn1.41:5.5.eng: After giving and using according to their means,

sn1.41:5.6.eng: blameless, they go to a heavenly place.”

sn1.42:1.2.eng: Giving what do you give beauty?

sn1.42:1.3.eng: Giving what do you give happiness?

sn1.42:1.4.eng: Giving what do you give vision?

sn1.42:1.5.eng: And who is the giver of all?

sn1.42:2.3.eng: Giving a vehicle you give happiness.

sn1.42:2.4.eng: Giving a lamp you give vision.

sn1.42:3.2.eng: is the one who gives monastic quarters.
sn1.42:3.2.comm: Here and SN 1.47:2.4 are the only places we find upassaya used for general “monastic quarters” rather than specifically for nuns. It is one of several Jain terms used by bhikkhunīs, perhaps because several prominent early bhikkhunīs, such as Bhaddā Kuṇḍalakesā, converted from Jainism.

sn1.42:3.3.eng: But one who teaches the Dhamma

sn1.42:3.4.eng: gives the gift of freedom from death.”

sn1.43:1.2.comm: Here the word for “food” is anna, which is a major theme of Vedic texts. From their creation the gods needed food (Aitareya Upaniṣad 1.2.1). The Divinity created two kinds of food for the gods, namely that offered in the fire, and that offered for beings not in the fire (hutaṁ ca prahutaṁ ca), or else the offerings at new and full moon (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.5.1–2). The point is that gods are dependent and hence not free. Taittirīya Upaniṣad 2.2.1 says that all creatures on the earth are produced by food, and pass back into food, the eldest of creatures, while 3.6–10 honors food as the foundation of life.

sn1.43:1.3.eng: So what’s the name of the spirit
sn1.43:1.3.comm: “Spirit” is yakkha. In early texts it sometimes means “mysterious manifestation of divinity”.

sn1.43:2.2.eng: and a clear and confident heart,

sn1.43:2.4.eng: in this world and the next.

sn1.43:3.2.eng: overcoming that stain, and give a gift.

sn1.43:3.3.eng: The good deeds of sentient beings

sn1.43:3.4.eng: support them in the next world.”

sn1.44:1.1.comm: The exact meaning of these items is open to interpretation. See Bodhi’s note for two readings; I offer a third. | Āvaṭṭa here might be read as “whirlpool”, “loop”, or “twist”.

sn1.44:1.2.eng: three the stains, five the spreads,
sn1.44:1.2.comm: Patthara is probably a “spread” of grass, such as was laid down in rituals.

sn1.44:1.3.eng: and the ocean, the twelfth whirlpool:
sn1.44:1.3.comm: If the ocean is counted as the last item, the total is twelve. Dvādasa can be an ordinal number. | I take the riddle as corresponding with the twelvefold “round” (vaṭṭa) of dependent origination. The “one root” is ignorance; the “two loops” are name-and-form with consciousness (DN 15:22.6); the “three stains” are ignorance, craving, and grasping; the “five spreads” are perhaps the five consequents starting with consciousness; and the “ocean” is transmigration itself.

sn1.44:1.4.eng: such is the abyss crossed by the seer.”

sn1.45:1.1.eng: “Behold him of peerless name <j>who sees the subtle meaning,

sn1.45:1.2.eng: giver of wisdom, <j>unattached to the realm of sensuality:

sn1.45:1.4.eng: the great seer treading the noble road.”
